programme.title: What's In the Barn?
programme.desc: An family farm in the mid-west contains houses, barns, outbuildings, trailers, grain silos and buses full of old stuff and perhaps the biggest stash of undiscovered old motorcycles in the country. The collection was put together by their unnamed father. Seller agrees to have Dale broker rare Excelsior for high-end client. Dale has the buyer, but will he outbid his own client for the exclusive find?

programme.title: What's In the Barn?
programme.desc: Matt is out for revenge. Last year Dale beat him badly at the Annual Vintage bike race in Barber, Alabama. But this year there is a whole new tale to tell. With just days until the race - Dale is secretly struggling to get the bike he beat Matt with last year up and working. Matt struggles just to locate a 100-year old bike. Matt's prayers are answered thanks to an old Catholic Priest he located who has possession of a bike. The priest might let Matt have the bike to race - but there are conditions. The toughest one: Don't tell Dale you have it. Can Matt afford to buy the bike and get it running in time for the race without Dale seeing it? Will Dale even get his broken bike started? And if they ever get to race, will Matt exact his revenge?

programme.title: What's In the Barn?
programme.desc: Built in the mid-60’s by eccentric engineer “Wild Bill” Gelbke, the Road Dog was, and still is, the largest motorcycle ever built. It utilized aircraft tubing, Corvette disc brakes, and a Chevy truck differential to keep it stable. The one-off creation disappeared when Gelbke did in 1978. Outflanked once when the bike was spotted and sold to a private collector in 1995, Dale has vowed to locate the machine and make Wheels Through Time its final resting place.

programme.title: What's In the Barn?
programme.desc: Big Time Motorcycle Auction

programme.title: What's In the Barn?
programme.desc: The RM Auction Company has worked with Dale before as a buyer, seller, historian, and caretaker at the prestigious Lee Hartung auction. But this event is no last minute rush to define one man’s treasures. This is a well calculated, time consuming, multi-media, and multi motorcycle and prized art deal.

programme.title: What's In the Barn?
programme.desc: Home Depot Senior Vice President, Gordon Erickson, is a huge fan of Wheels Through Time. He is also a huge supporter of the Wounded Warrior program. For years the hardware giant has been donating goods and services to help returning servicemen with their fix-it-up projects. Now they would like to go one step further and build a WWII military bike to raise awareness and funds. Only problem is where to get one? Enter Dale and an exhaustive, time sensitive, cross country search for a rare military machine.

programme.title: What's In the Barn?
programme.desc: Promoters of the prestigious Amelia Island Concours have called on Dale to develop a show and field bikes for an “Orphan Bike” show. They have defined orphan bike as extremely rare, that aren't a Harley nor Indian machines.

programme.title: What's In the Barn?
programme.sub-title: Time is Not On Their Side
programme.desc: For Dale and Matt sometimes the dotted line to treasure splits and heads in opposite directions. In this edition of What’s in the Barn, time is thrust to the forefront of this multi-state, long distance, north, south search. Timeless and priceless 110 year old bikes, antique cars, airplanes, and the infamous Egberts 1930 neon Harley-Davidson sign that coined the phrase “Ride a Winner” are high on this father and son’s list of “must haves”. The clock ticks, both literally and figuratively, on one rare time piece and two old-timer’s cars, bikes, and automobiles.

programme.title: What's In the Barn?
programme.desc: A California collector gambles on a big payday from his Crocker/Caddy combo.

programme.title: What's In the Barn?
programme.desc: “The Century Race”: Dale believes he found the bike that will help him beat a rival in an annual race of 100 year old motorcycles. But will it run?

programme.title: What's In the Barn?
programme.desc: “A Motorcycle Crime Story”: The horrific tale of a double murder over money and motorcycles.

programme.title: What's In the Barn?
programme.desc: “Yes, Dale there is a 100 Year Old Harley”: Dale hopes his labor of love becomes a prized possession when a six-figure Harley goes to auction.

programme.title: What's In the Barn?
programme.desc: A thousand bulging barns of choppers, bobbers, and board trackers are emptied and on display in the Quad Cities.

programme.title: What's In the Barn?
programme.desc: A vague tip leads Matt and Dale into a WWII era military warehouse and beyond.

programme.title: What's In the Barn?
programme.desc: A cross-country race to lay claim to some of the world’s most sought after works specials.

programme.title: What's In the Barn?
programme.desc: “12hrs. & Running”: Dale turns a surprise 60th birthday party into a challenge to his guests to start 120 of the rarest motorcycles in the world.

programme.title: Rutter's Detailin Garage
programme.desc: Nick Rutter walks you through step-by-step on how to remove stubborn bug splatter from your vehicle along with tips and techniques for using a waterless wash as well as a clay bar.

programme.title: Rutter's Detailin Garage
programme.desc: Nick Rutter provides tips and techniques for restoring dull, faded paint using a forced-rotation dual action polisher along with a graphene 3-in-1 ceramic polish, along with severe scratch and scuff removal.

programme.title: Truck U
programme.desc: Matt and Bruno are working on a 2006 Dodge Ram with a ton of problems…but why just make the repairs? Go better than stock!

programme.title: Truck U
programme.desc: Matt visits the Wheels for Hope Garage in Raleigh, NC and sees first hand how this organization is changing lives.

programme.title: Truck U
programme.desc: Matt and Bruno upgrade the Dana 35 rear end in a 2000 Jeep TJ to a much stronger Ford 8.8 one and do it for under $500.

programme.title: Truck U
programme.desc: Every light on your dashboard means something. Matt and Bruno diagnose and repair a vehicle that came to the shop to them with warning lights.

programme.title: Truck U
programme.desc: Nobody likes to fix a truck on the side of the road. That’s why there’s roadside assistance. Matt and Bruno take a stock F250 and turn it into a purpose-built Road Ranger.

programme.title: Truck U
programme.desc: With two days and a ton of truck parts anything can happen. Matt and Bruno put together build teams to see who can complete the toughest rig.

programme.title: Truck U
programme.desc: The Jeep Build-Off continues as the guys get a chance to finish their Jeeps and take them on a Geocaching race for all of the marbles.

programme.title: Truck U
programme.desc: The Jeep Build-Off continues as the guys get a chance to finish their Jeeps and take them on a Geocaching race for all of the marbles.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: For Rick Hendrick, the Corvette inspired his first car purchase, which ultimately led to the creation of his car dealership empire and motorsports teams. Mr. H, as he goes by, gives us a rare look inside of his personal Corvette collection and takes us to General Motors World Headquarters to talk with GM Vice President of Global Design, Ed Welburn, about how this iconic car came about. Country superstar Brad Paisley makes a cameo appearance to talk about his prized ‘Vette and the influence of cars on his music.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: The last car Elvis drove the evening he passed was his beloved Stutz Blackhawk. Ray discovers that the car has been preserved and heads to Graceland to check out this iconic piece of American music history. Ray and the team reveal the impeccable preservation of the car at Charlotte Motor Speedway with Rick Hendrick (“Mr. H”) and, arguably Elvis Presley’s biggest fan, Dale Earnhardt Jr. While at Graceland, Ray and the team also get an exclusive look at the paneled station wagon Elvis used to get in and out of Graceland in disguise. It’s an intimate look at the King’s incredible automobiles and their secrets that only Elvis knew.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: This episode takes an inside look at the famous racing L88 Corvette. From its history, to its successes and heartbreaks, to the stories of the men that drove it. Now, it’s a car world’s version of the Flinstones meet the Jetsons, as the Owens Corning Corvette, which clinched 22 straight race victories, challenges the new Corvette C7-R at Sebring International Raceway. The original Owens Corning team reunites for the challenge and our crew goes behind the scenes for the Corvette test drive of a lifetime.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: From break up to make up, Jeff Gordon and Ray reunite to go on a quest to find their Chevrolet Monte Carlo that claimed victory in their final race together at Phoenix, AZ in 1999. John Bickford, Jeff Gordon’s stepdad, makes the call that reunites the old team. Jeff and Ray look to bum parts off their boss, Rick Hendrick, to make their vision a reality: get the car, replace the parts as they were, make it run and get it to auction.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: One of the greatest battles in NASCAR history was Hall of Famer Richie Evans and rival speedster Jerry Cook. Ray is determined to uncover and revive the cars that made these men famous.Ray purchases one of Richie’s original #61 modifieds from Jimmy Spencer and restores it to its original glory while simultaneously building a replica of Jerry Cook’s #38. Throughout the build process, Ray uncovers stories about these legends through the eyes of guys who were in Rome, NY to witness it firsthand, like Robin Pemberton and Steve Hmiel.Both cars will hit the track at Martinsville, site of one of the greatest races in modified history and the tragic death of Richie Evans himself. Legends live again, as Ray recreates one of the racing world’s most celebrated rivalries on a track that has seen it all.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: General Motors VP of global design Ed Welburn takes AmeriCarna behind the scenes to talk about the history and development of the company’s concept cars that never made it to production. In a rare tour of the factory’s inner design studio, Ray gets an exclusive look behind the creative curtain at the GM plant in Detroit.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: In this episode, Ray celebrates the 50th birthday of the Ford Mustang through the lens of three distinct Mustang owners, who each hold a slice of the car’s incredible history. In 1964, Chicago schoolteacher Gail Wise unknowingly purchased the first ever Mustang 3 days before the car became available to the general public. Her husband reveals the incredible restoration that brought the earliest Mustang ever sold back to its 60’s glory. (Ford Motor Company knows she has the car and has verified it was sold before it was legal to sell.) John Grafelman is a farmer in Illinois and life-long Ford lover. A few years ago he found an old car hidden in a barn. It took some time, but he eventually convinced his friend to sell it to him. After some detective work, he discovers he purchased 1968 Ford Design Chief Larry Shinoda’s personal car that he tinkered with to invent the BOSS 302.Lastly, Ray travels to Dayton Ohio to interview Gale Holderman, the Ford stylist who won the company’s contest to draw and design the Mustang.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: Post-World War II, a large generation of American soldiers was looking for cars that mirrored the incredible sports cars they saw overseas in Europe. After searching for an affordable way to recreate these cars, one manufacturer responded with a durable, cost effective option: a line of fiberglass sports cars. Very few of these cars still exist but there are collectors who are constantly looking to save parts and pieces of these virtually unknown vehicles. We learn about these rare cars from Geoff Hacker and his team at Forgotten Fiberglass, and take a visit to the Smithsonian Museum, which houses a fiberglass car of its own. This episode presents a unique look at how the narrative of American wartime experiences often shaped the nation’s automotive demands.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: Ray explores buying a unique, hand built car the Schultz family has kept in their New Jersey home for years. The car was originally called the Schultz El Fierro but it’s officially titled in New Jersey as a “Schultz Special” from 1958. It was used to drag race and held numerous racing records, but most important to the family was that it was driven by the legendary Carroll Shelby. With a frame and style much similar to the Shelby Roadster, the Schultz family wonders if it inspired one of the most well known automobiles in America. In another epic New Jersey story, Ray finds Mario Andretti’s 1965 IndyCar. The catch: it’s completely in pieces hidden away in a garage. The iconic driver talks about his days on the track with that car and Ray attempts to negotiate a deal to buy the parts.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: How do you cast a car in a movie? What are the secrets to the build? Hollywood car designers give Ray the ultimate tour of some memorable movie cars, including a look at the recently found “Hells Chariot”, the last surviving car from Grease. We also hear the backstory to “Bumble Bee” from Transformers, take a look at the making of the tanks for Hunger Games and stumble upon the iconic 1958 Chevy Impala from American Graffiti.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: While visiting the estate of automotive genius and land speed record holder Willie Glass, Ray uncovers a set of extremely rare Ardun cylinder heads, which is a hot rodders dream discovery. He also visits the infamous H & H Flatheads outside of Los Angeles and discovers a surprise connection to the Earnhardt family.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: A massive sinkhole opened underneath the National Corvette Museum in Kentucky. Eight amazing cars were swallowed up, including the 1,000,000th Corvette. AmeriCarna was given exclusive access to document the removal of the cars from the sinkhole and the painstaking restoration of the 1,000,000th Corvette.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: On the beaches of Wildwood, NJ, an iconic vintage race, The Race of Gentleman, takes place annually: period cars, period dress, pure authenticity. Ray puts a car in the race with a very special driver, who turns out not to be a Gentleman.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: Scott Borchetta, CEO and Founder of Big Machine Label Group, and his brother, Mark, love racing just as much as anyone. From Indy to Nashville, Ray finds he has a lot in common with the Borchetta brothers. This celebrity-filled episode features musicians Tim McGraw, Cassadee Pope and IndyCar driver Josef Newgarden.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: In 1964, the United States sent a star-studded race team to England to educate them on drag racing. On that team was Bob Keith and his Dos Palmas car. After being lost for over 40 years, Ray uncovers car and puts together a plan to reunite the two once more. The restoration of the car takes an emotional turn with the loss of a friend.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: Blues legend Joe Bonamassa is looking for a surprise gift for his parents. With his love of cars and guitars, Joe has to get Ray and Mr. H involved. From Mopar muscle to Mr. H’s man cave to a concert performance from Joe, this episode has a lot of Drive.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: In the early 1900s, race tracks built of wood sprang up across the country drawing crowds of 50,000 and more. Ray and Xtreme sports superstar Travis Pastrana break down the Battle on the Boards.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: Ray finds an old T-Bucket that made a 133 mph pass at the Bonneville Salt Flats in 1951. The team brings the Woody Lee T back to life and attempts to match its original speed.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: Ray finds a Gurney Eagle in a garage on Long Island. He wants to put the coveted machine back on the track at Indy to honor Dan Gurney. After intense restoration and scouring the globe for a Gurney-Westlake engine, the Eagle soars again.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: Ray uncovers the infamous “Brawner Hawk” – from the Dean Van Lines team – that became the breakout car in the career of Mario Andretti. Ray enlists HOF mechanic Jim McGee to restore the vehicle and, along the way, discovers a replica with many of the car’s original parts. After an award winning stop at Concours Amelia Island, the car heads to the 100th running of Indy 500 where Mario Andretti himself gets behind the wheel.

programme.title: AmeriCarna
programme.desc: Dale Earnhardt Jr. wants Ray to help restore an El Camino, except add on a Laguna front end. It’s not a typical restoration, but it’s certainly a NASCAR performance-worthy restoration. Ray and the team build the car and then, in a bit of gamesmanship, challenge Kyle Tucker, owner of Detroit Speed, to a series of races against his award winning Camaro. But as always, Ray has an ace up his sleeve in Al Unser, Jr. as his driver.
